docs.lead_paragraph: LOOKED at one way, the surgeon general's new report is a comprehensive analysis of the sorry state of America's mental health care. Looked at another way, it is a primer in two political truisms: one, follow the money; two, beware every policy's unintended consequences. Consider the money trail: the report faults private insurance companies for failing to cover mental illness as much as physical ailments. But it fails to tell you that the federal government itself is guilty of the same stinginess. Medicaid, the government's insurance program for the poor, does not reimburse the states for the cost of treating most patients who need long-term care in state psychiatric hospitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: With a year-end deadline looming, state legislators and Gov. George Pataki have announced an impressive health care package that offers coverage to thousands of uninsured New Yorkers and helps pay for it by boosting the tax on a pack of cigarettes by 55 cents. The agreement also draws on funds from a nationwide tobacco industry settlement that is expected to bring in half a billion dollars a year. The negotiated package looks like a significant, and long-needed, expansion in state support for the three million New Yorkers who lack medical insurance. Equally important, it would maintain the financial ability of New York's hospitals to serve the poor and to educate physicians. The only disappointment is that the bill would set aside an average of $37 million a year for new anti-smoking programs, which is a considerable boost to the $20 million currently being spent but still short of what is needed to discourage smoking among adolescents.

docs.lead_paragraph: For several years, the big quest in biotechnology has been to determine the complete sequence of human DNA, the genetic code of life. Now, however, that task is nearing completion, and the biotechnology industry is facing an even tougher job -- deciphering that code so that new drugs and diagnostic tests can be developed. The coming post-sequencing era will bring huge changes to the industry. The causes and mechanisms of various diseases that now defy treatment will become known so that drugs can be developed much more precisely. Drug discovery will rely as much on software and databases of genetic information as it will on test tubes and white mice.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Constance B., 62, moved into her studio apartment in the Fordham section of the Bronx 19 years ago, she was a freelance writer and English tutor. Since then, she has lost her sight and suffered kidney disease as a result of acute diabetes. And she fears she may well lose her apartment because of rent increases. ''It's a struggle, because I'm on a fixed income,'' she said. ''Every two years my lease expires, and I have to pay the rent increase. Every two years my rent increases, but my income stays the same.''

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN decorative lights began appearing in stores last holiday season, Angela Cascello found the trendy outdoor icicle ones particularly appealing. But living in tight quarters in the lower level of a Selden home that was partly owned by her father, Mrs. Cascello had nowhere to hang them. This year she went out early and purchased four sets of the icicles. Her hope was that she could use them to dress up her brand-new Bellport home. She wasn't sure she would be living in the house for Christmas, but decided to take a chance and make the purchase.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE nation is suffering from a veritable epidemic of mental illness, according to a report last week by the surgeon general of the United States, which asserted that ''22 percent of the population has a diagnosable mental disorder.'' But how is mental illness defined? The standard reference used by therapists for diagnosis and for assigning insurance-payment codes is the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of the American Psychiatric Association. The most recent edition, D.S.M.-IV, which was issued in 1994, lists more than 300 kinds of mental disorders -- a far cry from the 22 illnesses identified in 1918 in the Statistical Manual for the Use of Institutions for the Insane, the precursor to the D.S.M.

docs.lead_paragraph: DOCTOR, lawyer, Indian chief -- well, not quite for Dr. Galina Feit, but how about doctor, builder, artist, parachute jumper? Dr. Feit was a gynecological surgeon in Russia until moving to the United States six and a half years ago. She taught herself English and, while working to gain credentials to practice medicine in New York -- she has her license but needs to do a residency -- she is pursuing a career she accidentally stumbled into. She is a builder, president of American Building Technologies, whose offices are in Croton-on-Hudson. As such, she has overseen construction of several luxury homes in the village, which are being offered by Coldwell Banker Realty.

docs.lead_paragraph: THAT deafening silence you hear is the sound of presidential hopefuls debating whether government should intervene in the wage-etting process to help people afford a better life. Today, it seems, everyone agrees that the market does this best. In the past, American politicians have split, often rancorously, over the issue. Still more profoundly, they were divided over tax cuts and social programs such as welfare, food stamps, child care, education and health insurance. Now there is broad agreement that whatever the specifics, government should limit itself to help families get along until the market finally raises their incomes.
